data.title: Local vote seen as harbinger of Rada elections - The Ukrainian ...
data.meta_description: Local vote seen as harbinger of Rada elections - The Ukrainian ...
data.text: Inside: • Former U.S. envoy on progress, setbacks in Ukraine – page 3 • Taras Shevchenko honored in two capitals – page 8 • Special section: Ukrainian Debutante Balls – pages 9-14 The Ukrainian Weekly Published by the Ukrainian National Association Inc., a fraternal non-profit association Vol. LXXX No. 13 THE UKRAINIAN WEEKLY SUNDAY, MARCH 25, 2012 John Demjanjuk dead at 91 A nasty battle marred by assault, intimidation $1/$2 in Ukraine Local vote seen as harbinger of Rada elections by Zenon Zawada Special to The Ukrainian Weekly John Demjanjuk in a photo taken in December 2011. PARSIPPANY, N.J. – John Demjanjuk, the former U.S. citizen who was appealing his 2011 conviction in Germany on 28,060 counts of accessory to murder at the Nazi death camp in Sobibor, Poland, died at a German nursing home on March 17. He was 91. The Bavarian police confirmed Mr. Demjanjuk was found dead early that day in his room in a nursing home in southern Germany. He had been suffering from bone marrow disease and chronic kidney disease. Mr. Demjanjuk, who through the years was accused of being a guard at several Nazi camps, denied that he ever served as a camp guard and insisted that he was a prisoner of war – a Red Army soldier captured by the Germans. He claimed he was a victim of mistaken identity. Mr. Demjanjuk’s German lawyer, Ulrich Busch, underscored that his client “died unconvicted and as an innocent man according to European and German law.” Dr. Busch explained that, according to the European Convention of Human Rights, anyone charged with a criminal offense is presumed innocent until proven guilty according to law, and in Germany that means once the final verdict is handed down on an appeal. Munich court spokeswoman Margarete Noetzel told the press that, under German law, because the defendant died before his final appeal was heard and because a person is presumed innocent until proven guilty, he is still technically presumed innocent. In a statement to The Ukrainian Weekly, Mr. Demjanjuk’s son, John Jr., said: “My father died a free man, innocent and not convicted since a successful appeal could not conclude upon his death. Over the last 35 years, the only criminal proceeding that did conclude resulted in an Israeli acquittal. “Since the accusations in Germany, I stated that it was a political farce as, at his advanced age and poor health, he could not survive another legal process. As Nazi Germany committed crimes against humanity by killing a forgotten several million Soviet POWs by a tortuous starvation and diseased death, today’s Germany intentionally chose such a surviving POW as a scapegoat to blame Ukrainians for the Nazi crimes by German criminals which historically went unpunished. (Continued on page 4) KYIV – The March 18 vote in the Kyiv Oblast town of Obukhiv offered a hint of what to expect for the October 28 national parliamentary elections – a nasty, even physical battle replete with fraud accusations, intimidation and violations, both before and on the day of the election. The day’s antics included an assault committed by a Party of Regions national deputy, disputes about the vote count and contradictory election law, as well as allegations of fraud techniques such as intimidation, denial of candidate registration, vote-buying, fake exit polls and ballot-stuffing. One of the chief contenders for City Council chair, Anatolii Shafarenko of the populist UDAR party, was denied access to polling stations to observe, his party reported. The nationalist Svoboda Party candidate, Valerii Vorobets, was denied registration altogether in mid-February, in an alleged violation of election law. Additionally, “the government used old ‘trusted’ technologies, including so-called ‘carousels,’” UDAR Deputy Chair Artur Palatnyi said in a March 18 press release. “What happened in Obukhiv was a warm-up and dress rehearsal for the future parliamentary elections.” The election was held to select a City Council chair to succeed Volodymyr Melnyk, a Party of the Regions member who died in an unusual car accident in October 2011. The declared winner was Oleksander Levchenko, also of the Party of Regions, who reportedly earned 39 percent of votes. Voter turn-out was unusually low at 41 percent, which National Deputy Iryna Herashchenko of the Our Ukraine- People’s Self-Defense faction said reflected the exhaustion most Ukrainians have for politics. In all, 28,600 voters cast their ballots at 15 local polling stations, reported the Committee of Voters of Ukraine (CVU). The CVU, led by Oleksander Chernenko, reported no falsifications, overlooking pre-election corruption such as the denied registration of Mr. Vorobets’ candidacy and the denied registrations of representatives from the Front for Change and UDAR – both leading opposition parties – to local election commissions. Mr. Chernenko’s claim of “more or less normal” elections was not supported by the UDAR and Svoboda parties, as well as the Spilna Sprava (Common Cause) civic movement and National Deputy Andrii Parubii of the Our Ukraine-People’s Self-Defense Bloc. Tymoshenko accused of “high treason” RFE/RL KYIV – A majority in the Ukrainian Parliament has voted to accuse jailed former Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko of committing “high treason” during negotiations on a 2009 gas contract with Russia. Ms. Tymoshenko is currently serving a seven-year prison term on charges she abused her office during those negotiations, which resulted in an increase in the price Ukraine paid for Russian gas imports. Lawmakers voted to endorse a parliamentary investigation claiming that Ms. Tymoshenko’s actions National Deputy Iryna Herashchenko (Our Ukraine- People’s Self-Defense) speaks to the press at the Verkhovna Rada two days after she was manhandled by National Deputy Petro Melnyk (Party of Regions) at a polling station in Obukhiv, Kyiv Oblast. Indeed, Mr. Chernenko’s credibility has been questioned by political observers ever since his predecessor, Ihor Popov, resigned from the CVU chairmanship in 2009 to join the Single Center party, which is closely affiliated with the Party of Regions. Since then, Mr. Chernenko has made assessments on several elections which were not considered by numerous political observers and players to be objective. “The sociological sampling of Obukhiv is a lot better for the opposition than Ukraine’s average, yet the victory was gained by the Party of Regions candidate,” Mr. Parubii wrote on his Ukrayinska Pravda blog posted on March 19. “Obviously, the vote didn’t occur without falsifications, evidence of which is the brutal attack on Iryna Herashchenko by a Party of Regions bandit with a deputy’s mandate, as well as ‘blue sweaters’ and fake exit polls,” he wrote. National Deputy Petro Melnyk of the Party of Regions violently grabbed the petite Ms. Herashchenko after she refused his demands that she leave a polling station before the vote count began. He argued that she didn’t have the right to witness the count, while she insisted she had the right to observe as a national deputy. “I realized that neither my status, nor personal relations, will save me from similar behavior by [my] colleagues from (Continued on page 4) UNIAN/Aleksandr Sinitsa “bear signs of high treason.” The report alleges that Ms. Tymoshenko acted “in favor of a foreign state” because her private company allegedly owed Russia’s Defense Ministry more than $400 million and she possibly faced criminal prosecution. Ms. Tymoshenko’s office dismissed the accusations as “complete rubbish.” The European Union and the United States have condemned Ms. Tymoshenko’s prosecution as politically motivated. (With reports from ITAR-TASS and the Associated Press)
